author: root
title: Worlds Together Worlds Apart Chapters 8
description: Review set for Mr Diffley's World History class

list.name: Vibia Perpetua
list.definition: A Christian martyr who was a noblewoman, said to have been a convert to Christianity as well as a wife and mother.

list.name: Constantine
list.definition: The first Roman emperor to convert to Christianity. He issued an edict of toleration in 313 and summoned the Council of Nicaea in 325.

list.name: Attila
list.definition: King of the Huns (434–453). He led many military raids on the Roman Empire and was known for his cruelty and destructiveness.

list.name: Romulus Augustulus
list.definition: The last Roman emperor, reigning from 475–476.

list.name: Justinian
list.definition: Byzantine emperor from 527 to 565, noted for his administrative reorganization of the imperial government and for his sponsorship of a codification of laws known as the Code of Justinian.

list.name: Khusro Anoshirwan
list.definition: Sasanian king (531–579). He was the most celebrated of the Sasanian kings and is considered to be the greatest ruler of the Sasanian Empire.

list.name: Chandragupta
list.definition: Indian emperor (reigned 320–335). He was the founder of the Gupta Empire, which is considered to be the golden age of classical India.

list.name: Xiaowen
list.definition: Chinese emperor (reigned 471–499). He was the first emperor to convert to Buddhism.

list.name: Empress Fang
list.definition: Regent for her son, Xiaowen, from 471 to 499.

list.name: Kumarajiva
list.definition: A Buddhist monk and scholar who was born in India and traveled to China in 401. He is credited with translating many Buddhist texts into Chinese.

list.name: Xuanzang
list.definition: A Buddhist monk and scholar who traveled to India in 627 and returned to China in 643. He is credited with translating many Buddhist texts into Chinese.
